Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world will need to produce more food to feed a projected 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, but the magnitude of the yield decline is uncertain. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. The results are relevant to the food security of the world and to the stability of global trade and prices.

Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized by optimally assembling multiple materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex and programmable responses. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. It also provides a general strategy for the design of complex and programmable mechanical systems.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the network with a large number of training examples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The proposed network architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed network architecture can be applied to other problems as well.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of the core at the time of the formation of the Earth. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than the nucleation of the hexagonal close-packed phase of iron, which is the phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The present study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, compared with controls, marijuana abusers showed attenuated DA responses in the brain, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine transporter binding potential (reflecting DA increases) and distribution volume (reflecting DA availability). The attenuated responses to methylphenidate were associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased craving. These findings are consistent with the notion that the reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is the most complex cognitive ability known, and it is also the most uniquely human. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict the majority of variance in the brain and behavior of human language processing. This suggests that the mechanisms of language comprehension in artificial neural networks and humans are similar. We discuss the implications of these results for the neuroscience and neurobiology of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most important challenges is to make DL more stable. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, and we explain it by showing that the existence of stable NNs is not sufficient for the existence of an algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is a major step toward making DL more stable.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a major topic of discussion in the scientific community. In this context, the classic experiment by the social psychologist Paul Meehl is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the experiment’s design flaws have been ignored. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its etiology is still not fully understood. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a human pathogen that is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that this pathogen is closely related to the leprosy bacillus, but has retained the ability to infect the nervous system. This finding suggests that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our results also suggest that the two leprosy bacilli have diverged from their common ancestor approximately 14 Mya. This is the first report of a pathogen that is associated with a reactional state in leprosy. (Show more)

The dynamics of quantum entanglement and entropy is a key open problem in quantum physics. It is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. Here, we provide a complete solution to this problem for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg spin chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle concepts. It provides a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of infinite system length and finite quench rate. We check our result for the ground state and the thermal state. Our approach opens the way to the systematic study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of models. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of the dynamics of other quantities of interest, such as correlations and dynamics of quantum chaos.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, and the development of a live attenuated vaccine is a promising alternative. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a segment of the spike protein, which was codon-pair deoptimized to reduce the viral fitness. The vaccine strain was further modified by deleting the furin cleavage site within the spike protein. The resulting vaccine is highly attenuated, yet still replicates efficiently in vitro and in vivo. In addition, the vaccine generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and robust protection against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model complex epidemiological data. The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in neuroscience and a popular topic in the popular press. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the product of both size and number of neurons, has received much less attention. This study shows that the evolution of brain power in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts. The most dramatic increase in brain power happened with the evolution of birds and mammals. This is followed by two smaller increases in brain power in core land birds and anthropoid primates. These results have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation, but its function in the cell is still not fully understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The process of disassembly is controlled by the cofilin family of proteins. In this work, we show that cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We demonstrate that the mechanical torque that cofilin induces on filaments is critical for the process. We propose that this mechanism is important for cells, where actin filaments are highly connected and under mechanical stress. Our work provides a mechanism for how cells can control the disassembly of actin filaments in a mechanical context. This is important for understanding the role of cofilin in cells. It may also lead to the development of new tools for controlling the dynamics of actin filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. This study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We found that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are related, but the Bantu population is also related to the Southeast Asian population. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is not only due to the recent admixture, but also due to the geography of Madagascar. This suggests that the island has been shaped by human activities for a long time. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the human colonization of the island. They also have implications for the study of the human population in the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

This paper provides experimental evidence for emotional contagion in a large-scale social network. The results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, and that this influence is not limited to in-person interaction. The results also suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not aware of the emotions that they are experiencing. The results are important because they suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not aware of the emotions that they are experiencing. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. The results have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on the translation of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can modestly alter the bacterial translation system and human cells. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the translation system and human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work highlights the importance of mRNA modifications in the translation of mRNAs. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a major theme in the history of life. We show that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. We also show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium. These results are consistent with the energetic model of body size evolution in the water.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a less efficient antiviral defense response at cool temperature. This is due, in part, to a less efficient induction of type I and type III IFNs at cool temperature. These findings have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and the role of the antiviral defense response in the cold adaptation of this virus. Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the type IV pili system of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is involved in sensing the mechanical activity of the pili, and in turn, regulating the expression of virulence factors. This is the first demonstration of a mechanochemical model for a bacterial chemosensory system.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and their effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a major contribution to the global discussion on the importance of pesticides in the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals is a major concern, as it could lead to the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible and/or resistant to current vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for the virus. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive surveillance effort to monitor the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in animals. This is especially important in light of the recent emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. Our findings have implications for the conservation of wildlife and the health of humans and animals. This study also highlights the importance of a coordinated international effort to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The world is moving toward a low-carbon future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of much research. However, the role of inflammation in AD is still not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, even in the absence of Aβ plaques. We propose that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is the primary cause of the neuron-derived inflammatory response. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is, however, still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. The results are supported by a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We argue that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by the Southern Levant by at least a century. This gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet fully understood. The results reported here provide evidence that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. The results are consistent with the existence of a compact, early molecular-collapse intermediate that is not part of the native structure. The results also suggest that the folding of the protein proceeds in more than one step. This is the first time that such evidence has been obtained for a large protein. The results are important for understanding the folding of proteins in general. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a critical mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, ApaH, is also capable of removing the cap from Np4-capped transcripts. However, ApaH is not the predominant decapping enzyme in cells experiencing stress. Instead, a second enzyme, RppH, is the primary degrader of Np4-capped transcripts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ termini by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We found that citrulline, an amino acid derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in the treatment of other immune-mediated diseases. View Full-Text

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that humans are the most abundant organisms on Earth, and we highlight the importance of humans in the biomass of other taxa. Our results are important for understanding the structure and functioning of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon that occurs in nature and is also observed in many complex systems. It is characterized by the fact that the system is in a critical state, and the system’s behavior is independent of the initial conditions. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum technologies. However, its properties are sensitive to external factors, such as temperature and strain. This work explores the possibility of tuning the properties of diamond by strain. We show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic bandgap can be opened, by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a framework for exploring the properties of other materials. The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of land plants is a topic of great interest. The role of the immune system in this process is also of great interest. The immune system of land plants is similar to that of animals, but it is not clear how it evolved. In this study, we show that a class of peptides with antimicrobial activity is expressed in nodules of a model legume, and that it is effective against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a link between the evolution of the immune system of land plants and the evolution of the immune system of animals. It also provides a possible mechanism for the evolution of the immune system of land plants.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also demonstrate that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome immediately after mating and continue to do so for at least 4 d. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The mechanism is similar to that of other proteins, but the effects on VWF are much greater than for other proteins. The results explain pathophysiology and suggest a mechanism for the development of new therapies. The results also suggest that the mechanism of action of VWF is similar to that of other proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is the first to comprehensively characterize the viral component of the human microbiome. It provides a database of over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. It also provides a resource for the study of virus–disease associations, with over 2,200 strong associations found. This study will be a valuable resource for the study of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can provide simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. The HSRL is capable of providing high-resolution observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL by analyzing a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the aerosol loading increased the droplet number concentration and decreased the droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth is of particular interest because it is believed to have been very hot, and thus, the evolution of life on the early Earth may have been different from that on the modern Earth. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the early Earth. The results of this study are consistent with previous temperature estimates based on isotopic evidence. This study also demonstrates the power of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive elements in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are activated by the influx of cations, and they are deactivated by the efflux of cations. The activation and deactivation of ion channels are controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end and the other at the selectivity filter. The activation gate is responsible for fast channel activation/deactivation, whereas the selectivity filter gate is responsible for slow channel activation/deactivation. We found that the BK channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 1 million deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to survive and multiply, and the process of invasion is central to this. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, increasing the cytoskeletal tension and reducing the bending modulus of the membrane. These changes are correlated with the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite is priming the host cell to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This is an important finding, as it suggests that invasion is a dynamic process, with multiple forces working together to facilitate entry. This could have implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external factors, such as temperature, pressure, and strain. This work explores the possibility of changing the properties of diamond by strain. We show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic bandgap can be opened, by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a framework for exploring the properties of other materials.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and severity of disease. The brain is thought to process language by first parsing it into a sequence of words, then into a sequence of phrases, and finally into a tree of nested phrases. The brain’s processing of sentences is a complex process that is difficult to study in humans. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences can be modeled as a sequence of merge operations, each of which is associated with a sudden increase in high-gamma power. The model of sentence processing that best fits the data is based on a left-corner parser that operates on phrases rather than words. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a hierarchical processor. The results also suggest that the brain may use a merge operation to build syntactic structures. Merge operations have been proposed by linguists to explain how the brain processes the structure of sentences. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a dual-functional protein that can either activate or repress the Wnt pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are functionally distinct. We demonstrate that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We have identified a critical downstream circuit element in this circuit, the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which is necessary for the rapid eating induced by LH stimulation. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is not mediated by the VTA, but rather by the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. This circuit is important for overeating and may contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both partners. The nitrogen-fixing symbiosis is particularly important, as it provides the plant with a major nutrient. However, the nitrogen-fixing bacteria can also cause disease. We have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the plant. This system can be used to control the bacteria to benefit the plant, such as in the case of disease control, or to prevent the bacteria from fixing nitrogen in the plant, which would be beneficial for the environment. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to improve the sustainability of agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is also one of the most threatened. The region is losing forest cover at an alarming rate, and the causes of this deforestation are not well understood. This study documents the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the effects are imprecisely estimated, and the results are likely to be driven by the program’s design. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in form and function, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. We demonstrate that the spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and that the spider can use the web to listen to the world around it. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to suit its needs. This provides a unique model for studying how animals can outsource and supersize their sensory organs. It also provides a new way to listen to the world around us.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the climate and health benefits of reducing aerosols are much larger than previously thought. This is because aerosols mask the anthropogenic warming, and removing anthropogenic particles liberates warming. We also show that the health benefits of reducing aerosols are larger than those of reducing greenhouse gases. This is because aerosols are more harmful to health than greenhouse gases. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This is a major step forward in the understanding of the health and climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases. It also provides a framework for estimating the health and climate benefits of future emission reductions. This framework can be applied to other regions and countries. It can also be used to estimate the health and climate benefits of emission reductions in other sectors.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. Vaccine candidates based on recombinant proteins are suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing to yield billions of doses annually, minimizing their manufacturing cost. These types of vaccines are well-established, proven interventions with multiple safe and efficacious commercial examples. Here we report an engineered sequence variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity after a single dose in mice compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered protein can be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. The role of ALK/Ltk in the development of neural crest-derived tissues has been studied in detail in the last decade. However, the ligand(s) that activate ALK/Ltk in vivo are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk are activated by secreted ALKALs. We further show that ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/Ltk by ALKALs and the involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. This study opens the way for the development of ALK/Ltk as therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the emergence of plague as a distinct pathogen, but the timing and geographic spread of this process are still debated. Here, we present 17 ancient plague genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. We show that plague spread rapidly across Eurasia, and that the earliest plague lineages were nonflea-adapted. We also show that the emergence of plague as a disease of fleas occurred much earlier than previously thought. These data provide a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its spread across Eurasia. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political consequences of masculinity.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of 1.5 Pg of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The results of this study have implications for the management of agricultural lands worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the mechanisms that underlie this process are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this compound. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red color of nectar is a highly favored trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the study of the evolution of color in nectar. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present genome data from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly derived from northern and central Europe, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The data also suggest that the genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period is more complex than previously thought.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 were investigated. The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are dependent on the host species. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The findings are of significance to the understanding of the origins of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. The rapid detection of these pathogens is critical for the development of appropriate public health response. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using mNGS in resource-scarce settings. The results of this study provide a foundation for the development of a coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance program in Southeast Asia. This program will better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to the study of emerging pathogens. The use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform, in combination with bioinformatics, clinical, and environmental data, is a powerful approach to the study of emerging pathogens. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand of DNA. It is a highly processive enzyme that is essential for the survival of all organisms. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it is not known whether such ribozymes can also synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. This polymerase can replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of in vitro RNA-based life.

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s most important carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees. Our results have important implications for the management of forests, which are a major source of carbon emissions.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of Th17 cells lacking the IFN-γ receptor. Instead, the development of colitis required the development of Th1-like cells from a subset of Th17 precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein C9orf72. We now report that astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, and that this toxicity is mediated by the expansion. This work provides a platform for rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that ameliorate the toxicity of astrocytes in ALS. This will enable the development of new therapies to treat this devastating disease. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now demonstrate that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the tick microbiota to more efficiently colonize the vector. We show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. IAFGP thereby perturbs the tick gut microbiota, which influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier—critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary transition in the history of birds, but the diversity of early members of this group is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the short-tailed bird group and adds important information about the evolution of the avian body plan.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and even to yellow, orange, and white. These colors are the result of the absorption of light by pigments in the skin. However, some vertebrates have distinctive colors, such as blue-green. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that the occurrence of high biliverdin concentrations in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. This is the first description of a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis in anurans. They also introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study contributes to our understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates. It also provides a model for the evolution of chlorosis in other vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG mRNA is methylated at a single position in the 3′-UTR, and this is a target for ALKBH5. ALKBH5-dependent m6A modification of NANOG mRNA is important for the maintenance of cancer stem cells in hypoxic conditions. Thus, ALKBH5 may represent a therapeutic target in cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a focus of research for decades. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future. (Show more)

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the recovery of life. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is constrained to 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle was not complete for ∼500 ka. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and the focus of vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that differ by a single amino acid, D614 versus G614. We show that the G614 mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Riordan (1986) to the case of tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical potential of an atom is the chemical potential of the electron in the atom. It is a fundamental property of atoms. We calculate the chemical potential of the electron in atoms under pressure, and we find that it decreases with pressure. This is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. We also find that the chemical properties of atoms change dramatically under pressure. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a major advance in the understanding of chemical properties under pressure.

Fire is a key natural process in many terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that human ignitions and suppression have been the dominant driver of fire regimes in the last century, and that this is likely to continue in the future. However, we find that changes in fire activity can reduce warming, potentially offsetting up to 10 y of CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This is due to the strong influence of fire on the global carbon cycle, which can mitigate the effects of greenhouse gases. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the role of human ignitions and suppression in the future. This is particularly important in fire-dependent ecosystems, where fire suppression has led to a loss of ecosystem function. Our study also highlights the need to understand the role of fire in the climate system in the context of other feedbacks, such as land use and albedo. This is an important step forward in understanding the role of fire in the climate system.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, including humans. The mechanisms by which animals regulate the composition of their microbiota are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is a mechanism for the regulation of the microbiota.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important in many domains. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work has implications for the study of language, gender, and violence.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single introduction scenario, which has been challenged by recent studies. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into Europe. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for humans, with a wide range of uses in the food, pharmaceutical, and cosmetics industries. The recent mass mortality of asteroids in the Northeast Pacific has led to a loss of ecosystem function and a significant economic impact. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids and provides a potential explanation for the recent asteroid mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is characterized by the presence of a small population of cells that are able to initiate and maintain the disease. In this study, we show that antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are able to kill leukemia cells in vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, we show that the antibody is able to block IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP in the treatment of other types of cancer.

We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique case in terms of its recent history. The settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth and a strong influence of geography on the genomic diversity. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar and of the human colonization of the Indian Ocean. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same binding site on the target genes. This is an example of a mechanism that can be used to regulate the expression of genes.

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their information is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that this is due to the lack of a quantitative framework to analyze and use this information. We propose a framework to convert the original categorical crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable, which can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our framework can be used to improve the use of crop experts in agricultural decision-making and to develop early warning systems for agricultural production anomalies.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to model, as it involves the loss of a major function, photosynthesis. We present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. We show that the transition to parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is the main driver of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is assessed using a high-resolution large ensemble. The results show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in SSA is strongly influenced by the spatial distribution of anthropogenic greenhouse gases. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, provides a unique link between the natural and the man-made worlds.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most important reactions in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction is unknown, and the only known enzymes are two unrelated proteins from plants, cyanobacteria, and bacteria. This study reveals that the two enzymes are related, and that they are part of a larger family of enzymes. The results also show that the two enzymes have different roles in photosynthesis. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of EAE. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages, but not in astrocytes, resulted in a reduction in the early stage of EAE, whereas deficiency in astrocytes resulted in a reduction in the later stage of EAE. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages was required for the generation and maintenance of disease. ASK1 signaling in astrocytes was required for the later-stage disease. These findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most severe in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results have important implications for the future of California and other regions of the world that are experiencing or will experience warming.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad spectrum of symptoms. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that behavioral inflexibility resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests a potential target for treatment. This study also provides a framework for identifying the converging functions of other genes in the brain. This framework can be extended to other complex diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the extent of negativity biases in a large, representative sample of the world’s population. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that the prevalence of negativity biases may be due, in part, to the fact that people are more likely to react to negative than positive information. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, ORAI1, and in the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, which result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats to other animals and humans are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration.
