Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that SHMT inhibition is effective in cancer, and that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue. However, formate is a poor inhibitor of SHMT, and we show that formate-dependent inhibition of SHMT is a feature of a subset of cancers. Formate-dependent inhibition is also a feature of a class of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and we show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This is the first report of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and the discovery of this class of compounds may lead to the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The proteins that are coaggregated in these inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but are themselves supersaturated in the motor neuron. This suggests that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The system is predicted to produce exotic atom–light interactions, including suppressed spontaneous decay, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal, and emission of light in a direction that is not parallel to the direction of propagation. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. The Cretaceous is often considered to be a period of global cooling and a reduction in plant diversity. However, this study shows that the Cretaceous was a time of great plant diversification, including the origin of aquatic plants. The study also shows that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader pattern of decline in the lives of those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate in tryptophan synthase with the isostere benzimidazole. This integrated approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding why benzimidazole does not react, while indole does. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal coronavirus infection. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. The data also support the testing of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial for the treatment of 2019-nCoV infection. This would be an important step forward in the fight against this emerging pandemic. (Show more)

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, including humans. The mechanisms by which animals regulate the composition of their microbiota are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is a mechanism for the regulation of the microbiota.

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested the effects of a brief, online intervention on the suspension rates of 1,682 students in 30 classrooms. The intervention was designed to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The intervention halved suspension rates in the participating schools. It also bolstered the respect that at-risk students had for their teachers. The intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the normal function of the genome. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylation on the transcription process. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the DNA alkylation status. The transcription process is stalled at alkylated DNA lesions, and the transcription fidelity checkpoint is activated. The transcription process is then rescued by the error-prone proofreading mechanism. The results from this study provide important mechanistic insights into the effects of alkylation on the transcription process. This work also provides a foundation for the development of strategies to mitigate the effects of alkylation on the transcription process.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked the sequential proteolysis required for virus entry. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a critical determinant of MERS-CoV tropism. We also found that uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked into endosomes, whereas precleaved MERS viruses used cell-surface proteases to enter the cell. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages may be important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to make a significant contribution to both environmental and health goals by altering the physical environment in which people make their food choices. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve large changes in meal selection by using simple nudging techniques. This has important implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable diets.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This study provides a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. The results suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences. This is an important finding for scholars and policy makers alike.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The virus responsible, SARS-CoV-2, has been shown to evade the immune system and spread rapidly. In this study, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This study provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. It also provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a challenge that arises when we have learned a lot from data. The challenge is to assess the strength of the associations that we have found. This is a challenge that is becoming more important in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference that can help us to address this challenge. We illustrate the use of these developments in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. It also provides a potential approach for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) were identified as oncogenic drivers in lymphoma and leukemia. Recently, two ligands were discovered that bind to and activate Alk and Ltk. Here, we show that these ligands are also important for the development of the zebrafish pigment system. We demonstrate that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for Alk and Ltk. We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the pigment system in the eye and the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the function of the augmentor ligands and their role in the development of the pigment system. It also provides a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. We also found that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual occurrence of influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone flow environment is a critical factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes are largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of a new strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examined geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. During the 21-y time period, the human-caused fire season was three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season and added an average of 40,000 wildfires per year across the United States. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a chemosensory receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms behind the disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise in viremia, the rapid decline in viremia, and the presence of a short eclipse phase. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the dynamics of the disease. The model can be used to guide the design of future experiments and to inform the development of new strategies to control the disease. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of anthropogenic stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key determinant of the onset of bleaching. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This is of particular importance given the widespread occurrence of coral bleaching as a result of climate change. View Full-Text

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system and microbiota. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors activate JNK signaling, which in turn triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response in the epithelium. The regenerative response, in turn, triggers tumor growth, and the cycle continues. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the epithelium. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This work may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients will relapse. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, and that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still debated. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption, which is the first of a series of volcanic eruptions that likely led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide the first global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also show that inland fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security and biodiversity conservation. This information can be used to inform the design of effective policies to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries and their contribution to food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. In contrast, the ability to regenerate in the adult nervous system is highly conserved in other species, including Caenorhabditis elegans. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is dependent on sensory activity, calcium signaling, and the activity of a kinase that is not known to be involved in regeneration. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a useful platform for discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Furthermore, they suggest that the mammalian nervous system may be more capable of regeneration than previously thought. Finally, they suggest that the mammalian nervous system may be more similar to C. elegans than previously thought.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity in all organisms. In plants, recombination is thought to be more constrained than in animals, with a tendency for recombination to occur only at specific sites. We describe a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which reveals a surprising pattern of recombination activity that is similar to that in animals. This suggests that the mechanisms that control recombination in plants may be more similar to those in animals than previously thought.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in cognitive and emotional functions. The present study provides a detailed description of the resting brain organization in health and disease, using a multimodal approach that combines functional MRI with positron emission tomography. The results show that the dominant resting network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant networks in rest and during task performance. The results show that the dominant network is deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a detailed description of the resting brain organization in health and disease, which can be used to understand the functional role of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. In addition, the 5′ cap structure is the target of the protein kinase, PKR. The existence of other modifications at the 5′ end of mRNA is unknown. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ modification in yeast, which we call NAD-RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is not found on pre-mRNAs that are 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this modification could modulate mRNA stability and translation. This could be important for the regulation of gene expression in the cell. (Read more)

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the development of psychological symptoms. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the composition of its volatile chemical profile. This profile is highly variable among different tomato species, and the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This pathway is unique to tomato and likely contributes to the distinctive flavor of this species. Understanding the mechanisms of tomato fruit flavor will be critical for the development of improved cultivars. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the impacts of these two factors on ecosystem functioning are not independent, but rather that they interact synergistically. We demonstrate that biodiversity loss increases the likelihood that species with thermal traits will be lost from communities, which in turn increases the vulnerability of ecosystems to environmental warming. Our results highlight the need to consider the impacts of both biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning together. This is particularly important in light of the current rate of biodiversity loss and the increasing frequency of extreme weather events.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for place learning, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network from other cell types in MEC. Our findings have implications for understanding the functional organization of MEC and its role in navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of both host and parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be important for the function of dopamine in the brain. This work may help to explain the role of dopamine in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cells that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. The SAN is also the site of the heart’s natural pacemaker potential, which is generated by the specialized cells of the SAN. This potential is important because it allows the heart to maintain a constant heart rate, even when the brain or other parts of the body are sending signals to change the heart rate. In this study, we show that the activity of the SAN is regulated by the activity of the SAN itself. This is important because it suggests that the SAN is not just a simple pacemaker, but also a complex and dynamic system that is constantly adapting to changing conditions in the body. This could have important implications for understanding the causes of heart disease and for developing new treatments for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice. We also show that Si pretreatment promotes the accumulation of Si in rice leaves and increases the expression of genes involved in defense responses. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a better understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism and may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to find favorable conditions. Thus, they have evolved a number of defense mechanisms to protect themselves from pathogens and other threats. One of the most important defense mechanisms is the production of defense-related molecules, which are often toxic to the plant itself. To avoid this, plants have evolved a number of detoxification mechanisms, which are often expressed constitutively. This can be a problem for the plant, as the expression of these molecules can be toxic to the plant itself. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules that can silence the expression of these molecules. This can be used to control the expression of these molecules and thus control the plant’s defense mechanisms. This work opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures to control the plant’s defense mechanisms.

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this study shows that small tributaries can be a major source of coastal nutrient pollution. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of coastal nutrient pollution. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings have important implications for the management of large water bodies worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is capable of providing work only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the ability to absorb work from a rare subset of environmental conditions may be a general feature of dissipative systems.

This study offers a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It provides a framework for understanding the effects of these antibodies on the brain, which can be used to develop new therapies.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. This study provides a detailed reconstruction of a major climate perturbation that occurred during a glacial period. The study also provides a unique opportunity to investigate the role of organic matter in the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is the largest buyer of deforestation-free commodities, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most common certification scheme. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for the palm oil industry, but it is an important tool in the toolbox. We hope that our findings will inform the development of certification schemes for other commodities. Our results also highlight the importance of the role of the supply chain in the effectiveness of certification. Our findings are based on a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia, which is publicly available. The data are available at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.10855510.v1.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved from bacteria to humans. The exocyst complex is involved in a variety of processes, including vacuolar trafficking, protein secretion, and endosomal recycling. The regulation of the exocyst complex is important for the maintenance of cellular homeostasis. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the mechanisms that determine sex are often the focus of intense study. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on sex determination in a vertebrate model system. We find that the multiple alleles in a polygenic sex determination system can produce a modular system of sexual variation, where the same trait can be sexually dimorphic in one population and monomorphic in another. This modular system of sexual variation can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles. Our results suggest that the modular system of sexual variation produced by polygenic sex determination may be a general feature of vertebrate sex determination. This system of sexual variation may also be a general feature of animals in general, as it is found in a wide variety of species.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that is a mixture of oxidized lipids and proteins. We show that the chelator deferiprone reduces the accumulation of lipofuscin in the retina of albino mice. This effect is associated with a reduction in the oxidation of the major lipofuscin component A2E and the degradation of A2E by light. These findings suggest that the accumulation of lipofuscin in the retina is associated with the oxidation of A2E and its subsequent degradation. This process is light dependent and can be inhibited by deferiprone. These results have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Siphonophores are one of the most diverse and abundant groups of pelagic cnidarians. They are characterized by the use of specialized side branches (tentacles) armed with nematocysts for prey capture. The evolution of these tentacles has been studied in the past, but the evolutionary history of specialization in this group is still unknown. Here we show that siphonophores have a strong evolutionary history with their prey, and that specialization in one prey type can lead to specialization in other prey types. Our results help to understand the evolution of specialization in this group, and the role of specialization in shaping the structure of marine food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important areas of hominin research. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of Acheulian technology. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that SHMT is a metabolic target of a pyrazolopyran scaffold, and that this scaffold is effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that formate, a one-carbon unit donor, is a potent inhibitor of SHMT. Formate is a common one-carbon unit donor in cells, and thus the discovery of formate as an inhibitor of SHMT is unexpected. Formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT in some cancer cell lines, but paradoxically a potent enhancer of SHMT inhibition in other cancer cell lines. This finding suggests that SHMT inhibition may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security that considers the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This is particularly important in low- and middle-income countries where forests are often the only source of food and nutrition security.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output and more efficient production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
